Source and Date: USAID accessed 27/02/2024; OCHA 19/02/2024; OCHA and UNCT Mongolia 25/03/2024
Justification:
The total pastureland is considered to be affected by the Dzud.The data on exact area affected is unavailable.

The total pastureland was chosen for landmass affected as the affected population are herder households. As at 20 December 2023, 90% of the country was at high or extreme dzud risk. As at 20 February 2024, more thab 80% of the country are facing dzud or near dzud conditions.

Source and Date: OCHA and UNCT Mongolia 25/03/2024; National Statistics Office of Mongolia 2020
Justification:
According to the OCHA Dzud Response Plan, the number of herder households being directly impacted by the dzud is 119,600 and number of herder households living in areas experiencing near-dzud condition 31,740. Therefore, total affected = 119,600 + 31,740 = 151,340 households.

Total population affected = 151,340 x 3.6 (average household size) = 544,824
No displacement reported due to the Dzud.
No injuries reported due to the Dzud.

Number of fatalities in affected areas in the last 6 months due to Dzud or related environmental conditions. Six months previous to the month the severity index (SI) is calculated are considered. For example, for the January 2023 version of SI, months considered will be July 2022 to December 2022.

Total number of fatalities for all the crises for the last 6 months. Six months previous to the month the severity index (SI) is calculated are considered. For example, for January 2023 version of SI, months considered will be July 2022 to December 2022.
Number of people in need estimated by OCHA in the Dzud Response Plan.

Source and Date: OCHA and UNCT Mongolia 25/03/2024; National Statistics Office of Mongolia 2020
Justification: Level 1 figure is calculated based on the ACAPS methodology using the equation: Level 1 = exposed population - affected population. Exposed population is the number of people who belong to herder households and affected population population is the number of people being directly impacted by the Dzud and people living in areas experiencing near-dzud condition.

Source and Date: OCHA and UNCT Mongolia 25/03/2024; National Statistics Office of Mongolia 2020
Justification: Level 2 figure is calculated based on the ACAPS methodology using the equation: Level 2 = affected population - people in need. Affected population is the number of people being directly impacted by the Dzud and people living in areas experiencing near-dzud condition.

Level 3 figure is calculated based on the ACAPS methodology using the equation: Level 2 = affected population - people in need: Level 3 = people in need - population in level 4. 

Number of vulnerable people who are are estimated by OCHA to be in need of immediate and lifesaving assistance are assigned to level 4. Numner of people in need is the number of people in need estimated by OCHA in the Dzud Response Plan.

There are no figures assigned for level 4 in the OCHA Dzud Response Plan. So, the 76,700 vulnerable people who are estimated by OCHA to be in need of immediate and lifesaving assistance as considered to be in level 4.
Not enough information to assign a portion of the people in need to this level.

The local population is not considered to be affected as they generally do not host any refugees.

Note: OHCHR states that the actual figures are considerably higher, however because information from some locations where intense hostilities have been going on has been delayed, and other information is still being verified at the time of publication. For example, Mariupol (Donetsk region), Lysychansk, Popasna, and Sievierodonetsk (Luhansk region), where there are allegations of numerous civilian casualties. The reliability is set as low for this reason.

According to flood response plan 2022, 20.6 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance.

All the people living in the flood affceted provinces are considered to be affceted and all of them are considered to be at least at stressed level humanitarian condition. Thus no one is considered to be at minimal level humanitarian condition.

All the people living in the flood affceted provinces are considered to be affceted, among those 20.6 million are in need of humanitarian assistance. So the rest of the people are considered to have stressed humanitarian condition.

As per INFORM methodology, Level 3,4, and 5 constitute the total People in Need. In 2022 flood, 30,000 people have been severely affected, so they are considered to have a severe humanitarian condition- Level 4. Thus, the rest of the poeple are considered to have moderate humanitarinan condition- Level 3.
According to OCHA 30,000 people have been severely affected.
No one was in extreme humanitarian need, so we did not consider anyone at level 5.

The statistics of persons displaced in the Republic of Mali because of the Complex Crisis, examines the displacement situations in this country. Persons displaced include; Refugees , Asylum Seekers, Returned Refugees, Internally Displaced Persons, Refugees in asylum countries, Returned Internally Displaced Persons.This figure summarizes displaced persons in the country and those living in other African countries.

Fatalities incurred in the Republic of Mali from the 01st of September 2023 to the 29th of February 2024. These fatalities are reported in the following 10 regions; Kayes, Koulikoro, Bamako, Sikasso, Ségou, Mopti, Tombouctou, Gao, Kidal, and Ménaka. This figure presents various events from ACLED in relation to the complex crisis which include; battles, violence against civilians, explosions, remote violence and riots.

Fatalities incurred in the Republic of Mali from the 01st of September 2023 to the 29th of February 2024. These fatalities are reported in the following 10 regions; Kayes, Koulikoro, Bamako, Sikasso, Ségou, Mopti, Tombouctou, Gao, Kidal, and Ménaka. This figure presents various events from ACLED in relation to the complex crisis which include; battles, violence against civilians, explosions, remote violence and riots.
Affected groups in the crisis-affected area, complex crisis in Mali include; internally displaced persons (IDPs), refugees, asylum seekers, returnees, and host communities in the Republic of Mali.

The statistics of persons displaced in the Republic of Congo examines the displacement situations in this country. Persons displaced include; refugees and asylum-seekers from the neighboring Central African Republic (CAR) and the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and internally displaced persons mainly due to armed conflict in the Pool department and recurrent flooding in the Likouala, Plateaux, Brazzaville and Pointe-Noire departments.

Fatalities incurred in the Republic of Congo from the 01st of September 2023 to the 29th of February 2024. These fatalities are reported in the following regions; Bouenza, Cuvette, Cuvette-Ouest, Kouilou, Lékoumou, Brazzaville, Likouala, Niari, Plateaux, Pool, Sangha, and Pointe Noire. This figure presents various events from ACLED in relation to the complex crisis which include; battles, violence against civilians, explosions, remote violence and riots.

Fatalities incurred in the Republic of Congo from the 01st of September 2023 to the 29th of February 2024. These fatalities are reported in the following regions; Bouenza, Cuvette, Cuvette-Ouest, Kouilou, Lékoumou, Brazzaville, Likouala, Niari, Plateaux, Pool, Sangha, and Pointe Noire. This figure presents various events from ACLED in relation to the complex crisis which include; battles, violence against civilians, explosions, remote violence and riots.
Affected groups in the crisis-affected areas of the complex crisis include; refugees, asylum seekers, and internally displaced persons.

This figure presents various events from ACLED in relation to the Anglophone Crisis which include; battles, violence against civilians, explosions, remote violence and riots.

Fatalities incurred in Cameroon from the 01st of September 2023 to the 29th of February 2024 in all crises. These fatalities are reported in the 8 regions; Far-north, Adamawa, East, Center, West, Littoral, Northwest and Southwest regions. This figure presents various events from ACLED in relation to the Multiple Crises which include; battles, violence against civilians, explosions, remote violence and riots.

Affected groups in the crisis-affected area in the Anglophone Crisis in Cameroon include; refugees, internally displaced persons, asylum seekers, returnees, and outgoing refugees. This group of persons are either residing or displaced in the neighbouring regions like; the Center, West, Littoral and Adamaoua region but mostly in the Northwest and Southwest regions.

The statistics of persons displaced in Cameroon because of the CAR Refugee Crisis, examines the displacement situations in this country. Persons displaced include; Refugees and Returned Refugees. This figure summarizes displaced persons in 3 Northeastern regions (Adamawa, East and North regions); and those living in neigbouring Central African Republic.

Fatalities incurred in Cameroon from the 01st of September 2023 to the 29th of February 2024. These fatalities are reported in the 3 Northeastern regions (Adamawa, East and North regions). Between 1 January and 24 December, over 30,386(9)** measles** cases, including 233 deaths (0.77 per cent) were reported across Ethiopia, mainly from the five regions of SWEP (36 per cent), Oromia (23 per cent), Amhara (16 per cent) and Somali (10 per cent) representing 89 per cent of the cases. With regards to cholera, the outbreak continues to affect 11 regions with close to 29,380 cases, including 421 deathsand a cumulative case fatality rate (CFR) of 1.43 per cent between January and 23 December 2023, according to the Ethiopian Public Health Institute.  We sum Measles and Cholera cases to have an approximation of the total number of illness cases reported (excluding malaria which is expressed in terms of million cases; 3.7 million(8)** cases** between 1 January and 17 December this year.). In TOTAL we have 30,386 +  29,380 = 59766. there is no info on illness reported in kenya and somalia.

In December 2023, 29,636 migratory movements were observed at flow monitoring points (FMP) in Djibouti, with a daily average of 956 migratory movements. Migration flows observed across all FMPs increased slightly by 29 per cent compared to November 2023 during which 22,968 movements were recorded. People involved in the mixed migration in as of December 2023. However, this figure has some limitations. The spatial and temporal coverage of the surveys carried out is partial and does not allow all migratory flows in the country to be captured. The data presented in this report mainly shows migration trends. Furthermore, it is possible that migrants crossing several FMPs may be counted for more than once. Thus, the total number of migrants observed at the FMPs does not necessarily reflect the true migratory flows in each region. It is also worth highlighting that thenumber of enumerators responsible for data collection can change from one month to the other, which can partly explain some changes in the flows observed. In addition, the data on thevulnerabilities are based on direct observations by the enumerators and should only be taken asan indication. All data included in this report are based on partial observations and are notrepresentative of the entire migrant population. IOM assures that the data included in this report is reliable, but stresses that it does not provide a complete picture of migration movements inDjibouti.

Migration flows observed across all FMPs increased slightly by 29 per cent compared to November 2023 during which 22,968 movements were recorded. However, this figure has some limitations. The spatial and temporal coverage of the surveys carried out is partial and does not allow all migratory flows in the country to be captured. The data presented in this report mainly shows migration trends. Furthermore, it is possible that migrants crossing several FMPs may be counted for more than once. Thus, the total number of migrants observed at the FMPs does not necessarily reflect the true migratory flows in each region. It is also worth highlighting that thenumber of enumerators responsible for data collection can change from one month to the other, which can partly explain some changes in the flows observed. In addition, the data on thevulnerabilities are based on direct observations by the enumerators and should only be taken asan indication. Only Amanat Al Asimah (Sana'a City), Aden, and Lahj are considered exposed, as they host refugee numbers higher than 10,000 + the total population of the refugees and asylme seekers and migrants in Yemen.

Total population of the refugees, asylum-seekers and migrants are considered affected as they are among the most marginalized and vulnerable groups in Yemen, and are largely dependent on external humanitarian assistance to meet their basic needs.

The figure represents the total number of fatalities between 01 September 2023 and 22 March 2024

Only Refugees and asylum-seekers and Migrants are considered PiN. The total population of the Refugees, asylum-seekers and migrants are among the most marginalized and vulnerable groups in Yemen and are largely dependent on external humanitarian assistance to meet their basic needs. To estimate the humanitarian conditions for the SI, we are applying IPC of food security phase classification of Ma’rib as it is the most sever classification in Yemen and because similarity as Ma’rib sever humanitarian condition is partially driven by the huge IDPs whose humanitarian condition would more resemble the conditions of migrants relatively compared to host community.

Thus, the percentages of IPC Ph 5 and Ph 4 were used to multiply by the people affected to get L5, Ph3 to get L4, Ph2 at L3. This means 20% of affected were pLaced in L5, 39% in L4, and 20% in L3. 

This is a conservative under estimation as it only takes food security aspect in determining the humanitarian condition instead of a multi-sectorial humanitarian conditions.

The figure takes into account migration and emigration trends, including new population dynamics following the 2011 Syrian conflict. The figure represents the Estimated Population of all Jordan governorates, as of 8 March 2024.

Source and Date: DOS accessed on 08/03/2024 ; UNHCR accessed on 08/03/2024
Justification: Around 90% of the registered Syrian refugees live in Amman, Irbid, Mafraq and Zarqa. Therefore, only these four governorates were counted in the affected landmass. Each of the four governorates has more than 20,000 Syrian refugees per admin 1 level.

Source and Date: DOS accessed on 08/03/2024 ; UNHCR accessed on 08/03/2024
Justification:
The figure represents the Estimated Population of the 4 governorates, at End-year 2023. According to the Jordanian Department of Statistics immigration and emigration, including of Syrian refugees after 2011, are already taken into account in their annual population estimates. Therefore, the number of people exposed is the sum of the estimated population of the four governorates hosting around 90% of the registered Syrian refugees: Irbid, Amman, Mafraq and Zarqa. Each of the four governorates has more than 20,000 Syrian refugees per admin 1 level.
To avoid double counting UNHCR refugee figures per admin level 1 are therefore not added. The figure might thus be an overestimation of the total number of people exposed.

The figure represents Syrian refugees in Jordan (registered Syrian refugees with UNHCR as of 29 February 2024+ the Unregistered Syrian refugees) + Palestine refugees from Syria + host community members in need. For the host community, UNHCR's 3RP 2023 numbers were used in stead of 2024 as they show significant jump with no explanation for the change in numbers. Per 3RP 2023, 520,000 million of the host communities are in need.

This figure has low reliability since the number of unregistered Syrian refugees is an estimation (The total number of refugees  was provided by the Government of Jordan which might be over- or under-estimated and the unregistered was obtained by subtracting the current number of registered Syrian refugees from the estimated total figure).

Source and Date: UNHCR accessed on 08/03/2024 ; UNRWA accessed on 12/03/2024 ; 3RP 02/02/2023
Justification: The figure represents the number of (Registered Syrian refugees as of 29 February 2024 (639552)+ Unregistered Syrian refugees (660448)+ Palestine refugees from Syria (19000)}.This figure has low reliability since the number of unregistered Syrian refugees is an estimation (The total number of refugees - 1,300,000 people- was provided by the Government of Jordan which might be over- or under-estimated and the unregistered was obtained by subtracting the current number of registered Syrian refugees from the estimated total figure).

PiN = Syrian refugees in need per 3RP 2024 + Host community in need per 3RP 2023. 

3rp 2024 doesn’t specify humanitarian conditions level for Syrian refugees. Thus, for humanitarian conditions, CARI food insecurity indicators by WFP for 2023 Q1 were used. The food insecurity of refugees in host community were used as the majority of the Syrian refugees reside outside the camps.

Per WFP CARI, 2% of Syrian refugees in host community are severely food insecure, 61% moderately insecure, 37% food insecure. 

For the SI, an adjustment is made to place the 0% at Level 5, the 2% who have borderline consumption at Level 4, 61% at Level 3. 

For the host community, UNHCR's 3RP 2023 numbers were used in stead of 2024 as they show significant jump with no explanation for the change in numbers. Per 3RP 2023, 520,000 million of the host communities are in need. For the SI, all of them were placed at Level 3.

Source and Date: DOS accessed on 08/03/2024 ; UNHCR accessed on 08/03/2024 ; 3RP 16/01/2024 ; 3RP 02/02/2023

Therefore Iraq conflict crisis displacement figures includes:

Syrian refugees figures based on UNHCR were not included in this figure as they are included separately in the Syrian Refugees Crisis. 

This figure is an estimate since it is hard to capture the accurate number Iraqi who departures the country because of the conflict and IDPs who are not registered. The displacement figure is higher than the people affected or people in needs. As not every displaced individuals or returnees are in needs or affected based on the recent HNO 2022.

• Incoming refugees

• Returnees
• Outgoing refugees and asylum seekers and outgoing migrants

Therefore Iraq conflict crisis displacement figures includes,
• Total number of IDPs  as of 31 December 2023 based on IOM’s Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) 
• Incoming Syrian refugees as of 31 December 2023 based on UNHCR 
•  Incoming Palestinian refugees in Iraq as of April 2023         • Returnees  as of 31 December 2023 based on IOM’s Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) 

This figure is an estimate since it is hard to capture the accurate number Iraqi who departures the country because of the conflict and IDPs and refugees who are not registered.

Source and Date: UNHCR accessed on 15/03/2024 ; UNHCR 21/06/2023 ; OCHA 27/03/2022 ; UNHCR 23/03/2021;  3rp Syria Crisis 16/01/2024
Justification:
The accumulation of 3, 4, &5 is equal to PiN of the conflict crisis and Syrian Refugees. 
The country level number represents the sum of PiN from the 2022 HNO (2.5 m) and int. displacement numbers including Syrian refugee. The severity needs of the 
Conflict: 2022 HNO; the Severity Classification: minimal, stress, severe, extreme, and catastrophic. Level 3, 4 & 5 are calculated according to the number of people classified  by severity level and the number of people in need at that level using OCHA needs summary. Redistribution SI levels for humanitarian conditions level 3 equal HNO needs minimal + stress + severe, Level 4 euals HNO needs extreme, and level 5 equals HNO needs catastrophic.
Syrian refugees: All Syrian refugees resident in Iraq are considered in need and members of impacted communities based on the 3RP 2024. 

3RP, doesn’t specify humanitarian conditions level for Syrian refugees. Thus, for humanitarian conditions, CARI 2022 numbers and HNO methodology for FSC humanitarian condition levels were used. Per HNO, “poor consumption” falls into “catastrophic’ and “extreme”, while “borderline consumption” falls into “severe.”

Per CARI and MSNA, 1% of Syrian refugees experience poor consumption while 7% are borderline. For the SI, an adjustment is made to place the 1% who have poor consumption at Level 5, the 7% who have borderline consumption at Level 4, the remaining at Level 3.

This is an conservative underestimation for level 5 and 4 as it takes only one sector into account.

Source and Date: UNHCR accessed on 15/03/2024 ; UNHCR 21/06/2023 ; OCHA 27/03/2022 ; UNHCR 23/03/2021;  3rp Syria Crisis 16/01/2024
Justification:
The accumulation of 3, 4, &5 is equal to PiN of the conflict crisis and Syrian Refugees. 
The country level number represents the sum of PiN from the 2022 HNO (2.5 m) and int. displacement numbers including Syrian refugee. The severity needs of the 
Conflict: 2022 HNO; the Severity Classification: minimal, stress, severe, extreme, and catastrophic. Level 3, 4 & 5 are calculated according to the number of people classified  by severity level and the number of people in need at that level using OCHA needs summary. Redistribution SI levels for humanitarian conditions level 3 equal HNO needs minimal + stress + severe, Level 4 euals HNO needs extreme, and level 5 equals HNO needs catastrophic.
Syrian refugees: All Syrian refugees resident in Iraq are considered in need and members of impacted communities based on the 3RP 2024. 

3RP, doesn’t specify humanitarian conditions level for Syrian refugees. Thus, for humanitarian conditions, CARI 2022 numbers and HNO methodology for FSC humanitarian condition levels were used. Per HNO, “poor consumption” falls into “catastrophic’ and “extreme”, while “borderline consumption” falls into “severe.”

Per CARI and MSNA, 1% of Syrian refugees experience poor consumption while 7% are borderline. For the SI, an adjustment is made to place the 1% who have poor consumption at Level 5, the 7% who have borderline consumption at Level 4, the remaining at Level 3.

This is an conservative underestimation for level 5 and 4 as it takes only one sector into account.
